Title: Phylogeny of Zapoteca (Fabaceae: Caesalpinioideae)
Keywords:
Phylogenetic analyses 路 Taxonomy 路 Neotropics 路 ETS, ITS,
trnL-trnF 路 Bayesian inference
Abstract:
The legume genus Zapoteca is separated from the genus
Calliandra by having pollen arranged in 16-grained polyads (compared to
8-grained polyads in Calliandra). As currently circumscribed, Zapoteca
contains 22 species and 13 subspecies placed in five subgenera. This
study included 20 species and 11 subspecies representing all five
subgenera. Representative species from the closely related genera
Calliandra, Havardia, Pithecellobium and Viguieranthus were also
included, along with the more distantly related species Senegalia
senegal and Vachellia farnesiana. The aims of this study were to test
the monophyly of Zapoteca and investigate phylogenetic relationships
within the genus. Total-DNA was extracted from leaf material and the
nuclear ETS and ITS, and plastid trnL-trnF regions were amplified.
Additional sequence data were downloaded from GenBank and the data sets
were analyzed using Bayesian inference. My results show that Zapoteca is
monophyletic and that the monospecific subgenera (subg. Nervosa and
subg. Aculeata) are resolved as separate lineages within the genus,
subg. Nervosa (containing Z. nervosa) as sister to all remaining taxa of
Zapoteca. Subgenera containing more than one species (subg. Amazonica,
subg. Zapoteca and subg. Ravenia) are shown to be non-monophyletic. Two
subspecies of Z. caracasana, subsp. caracasana and subsp. weberbaueri,
are found together in a clade. Furthermore, Zapoteca tehuana and the
subspecies Z. caracasana subsp. weberbaueri, Z. portoricensis subsp.
portoricensis, Z. formosa subsp. gracilis and Z. formosa subsp. schottii
are shown to be monophyletic. However, the subspecific classifications
of Z. formosa and Z. portoricensis are not supported and should be
revised.
